metadata.case_name: Messrs. Madan Mohan Damma Mal Ltd. & Om Prokash Manglik v. Calcutta Corporation

facts.text: Messrs. Madan Mohan Damma Mal Ltd. (appellant No. 1) sent consignment of mustard oil, about 499 maunds, from Firozabad to itself at Calcutta in tank wagon No. 75612 on December 25, 1954.
Wagon placed at Pathuriaghat siding, Calcutta at about 8.45 a.m. on January 3, 1955.

Dr. Nityananda Bagui, Food Inspector, accompanied by police officers, took three samples of mustard oil from wagon after arranging purchase with Om Prokash Manglik (appellant No. 2, Manager) found near wagon; paid annas eight for 12 ounces; samples in three phials, properly sealed; one given to appellant No. 2, two kept by Dr. Bagui.
One sample sent by Dr. Bagui to Public Analyst same day (January 3, 1955).
Ashit Ranjan Sen, Public Analyst, examined sample on January 3, 1955 but could not come to positive opinion; reported on January 4, 1955 that oil adulterated.
Dr. Bagui seized tank wagon that evening, sealed with Corporation seal, left in custody of appellant No. 2.
Oil in tank allowed to be removed to godown of appellants on January 6, 1955; godown lock sealed with Corporation seal.
Detailed report from Ashit Ranjan Sen on January 24, 1955 confirming adulteration.
Dr. Bagui filed complaint against appellants on February 4, 1955 for selling and keeping for sale adulterated mustard oil (adulterated with groundnut oil).

During trial, on application by appellants, trial court ordered despatch of third sample phial (in custody of Corporations Health Officer) to Director of Health Services, Government of West Bengal for analysis.
Third sample analysed by Dulal Chandra Dey (Court Witness No. 1); found adulterated with groundnut oil; report signed by Dr. S. K. Chatterjee, Deputy Director.
Appellants sent their sample to Om Prakash, Oil Expert to U.P. Government; reported July 27, 1955 that sample conforms to Agmark Specification, free from adulterants; report not proved.
Deputy Commissioner of Police, Enforcement Branch sent sample of mustard oil on January 10, 1955 to Public Analyst, Food Water, West Bengal Public Health Laboratory.
Sri S. N. Mitra (D.W. 7) examined police sample; saponification value 173.3, iodine value 105; approximated to genuine mustard oil standards but not declared genuine; benefit of doubt.
No good evidence that sample to Sri Mitra was from appellants' tank wagon; Dr. Bagui did not depose about police taking sample.
Kalidas Ganguli, Sub-Inspector, deposed police took one sample sealed with Corporation seal.
Courts below found oil adulterated with groundnut oil, appellants in possession and stored for sale via presumption under s.462(4) not rebutted.
Ashit Ranjan Sen: B.R. Index at 40°C 60.4, Belliers test positive (turbidity at 28°C).
Dulal Chandra Dey: saponification 175.5, iodine 106.8, turbidity at 27°C, indication of linseed oil.
Appellant No. 2 took delivery of wagon from railway on January 3, 1955 prior to sample taking.

Arrangements between U.P. Oil Millers Association and Deputy Commissioner of Police, Enforcement Branch; proceedings June 9, 1954; letter Exhibit R from appellants to Association Secretary at 10 a.m. January 3, 1955: 'Please arrange for sample and test... so that we may take delivery only if pure'.
Mahendra Kumar Gupta (D.W.1), Chemist of appellants' mill, deposed he took sample and found genuine; no certificate accompanied railway receipt.

legal_issues.text: Whether the mustard oil in the appellants' tank wagon was adulterated with groundnut oil.
Whether the appellants were in possession of the oil when the sample was taken.
Whether the presumption under sub-s.(4) of s.462 of the Calcutta Municipal Act, 1951 that the oil was stored for sale was rebutted.

petitioner_arguments.text: Findings on adulteration incorrect; relied on reports of Om Prakash (pure) and Sri Mitra (approximates genuine).
Not in possession of oil when sample taken; no presumption under s.462(4).
Presumption that oil stored for sale rebutted by arrangements with U.P. Oil Millers Association, Deputy Commissioner Enforcement Branch, and letter Exhibit R requesting test before delivery.

respondent_arguments.text: Oil adulterated based on analyses by Ashit Ranjan Sen and Dulal Chandra Dey; police sample not established from wagon.
Appellants in possession; appellant No. 2 took delivery prior to sampling.
Presumption under s.462(4) not rebutted; arrangements and letter do not prevent sale.

court_reasoning.text: Analyses by Sen (B.R. Index 60.4, Belliers positive at 28°C) and Dey (saponification 175.5, iodine 106.8, turbidity 27°C) confirm adulteration; Mitra's report on unlinked sample and gives benefit of doubt, not conclusive purity.
Appellant No. 2 present, arranged purchase, wagon delivered prior as he could not open without delivery; circumstances establish possession.
No legal restraint from selling adulterated oil via alleged arrangements; letter Exhibit R seeks test before delivery but silent on impure oil; device to hinder authorities; presumption not rebutted.

holdings.text: Mustard oil adulterated with groundnut oil.
Presumption under s.462(4) that oil stored for sale not rebutted.
Conviction under s.462 of Calcutta Municipal Act, 1951 correct.

statutes_cited.name: Calcutta Municipal Act, 1951 (W.B. XXXIII of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of storing adulterated mustard oil for sale; presumption under sub-s.(4) that article in possession of accused stored for sale unless rebutted.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by special leave, affirmed Calcutta High Court order upholding conviction of appellants under s.462 of Calcutta Municipal Act, 1951 by Municipal Magistrate.

key_quotes.text: "the finding of the Courts below that the mustard oil in the appellants tank wagon was adulterated is correct."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms adulteration based on expert analyses.

key_quotes.text: "We therefore hold that the appellants were in possession of the oil in the tank wagon when Dr. Bagui took samples of the oil from it."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the so-called arrangement with the Enforcement Branch of the Police and the consequent letters... seem to be a subtle device to make things difficult for the proper authorities"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects rebuttal of presumption under s.462(4).
